The Dirichlet and Neumann and Dirichlet-to-Neumann problems in quadrature, double quadrature, and non-quadrature domains

Steven R. Bell Mathematics Department, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907 bell@math.purdue.edu
Abstract.

We demonstrate that solving the classical problems mentioned in the title on quadrature domains when the given boundary data is rational is as simple as the method of partial fractions. A by-product of our considerations will be a simple proof that the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map on a double quadrature domain sends rational functions on the boundary to rational functions on the boundary. The results extend to more general domains if rational functions are replaced by the class of functions on the boundary that extend meromorphically to the double.

Key words and phrases:
Schwarz function, Szegő kernel
1991 Mathematics Subject Classification:
30C40; 31A35
Research supported by the NSF Analysis and Cyber-enabled Discovery and Innovation programs, grant DMS 1001701

1. Introduction

It has recently come to light that double quadrature domains in the plane exist in great abundance and that they can be viewed as replacements for the unit disc when it comes to questions of computational complexity in conformal mapping and potential theory. They are especially useful in the multiply connected setting. The “improved Riemann mapping theorem” described in [11] and further expounded upon in [9] allows one to map domains in the plane, even multiply connected domains, to nearby double quadrature domains, thus providing the means to pull back objects on double quadrature domains to the original domain. Double quadrature domains share many of the beautiful and simple properties of the unit disc. The purpose of this paper is to explain methods for solving some of the classical problems of potential theory in quadrature domains that are every bit as simple as similar problems on the unit disc. In fact, the methods will be shown to be analogous to the method of partial fractions from freshman calculus.

In this paper, we will consider problems in potential theory with rational boundary data in two special types of domains. The first type will be bounded quadrature domains with respect to area measure without cusps in the boundary. We shall call such domains area quadrature domains. The second type will be area quadrature domains which are also quadrature domains with respect to boundary arc length. We shall call such domains double quadrature domains. We refer the reader to [11] for the precise definitions of these domains and for a summary of their basic properties. The theory of area quadrature domains was pioneered by Aharonov and Shapiro in [1] in the simply connected setting and by Gustafsson [16] in the multiply connected setting. Quadrature domains with respect to boundary arc length were studied by Shapiro and Ullemar in the simply connected setting in [20] and by Gustafsson in [17] in the multiply connected setting. Good references for information about quadrature domains, their usefulness, and the history of the subject are the book [14], the papers [18] and [12] therein, and the book [19].

We now list some of the key properties of area and double quadrature domains that we will need in what follows. To begin, assume that Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is an area quadrature domain. Then Ωnormal-Ω\Omega has a boundary consisting of finitely many non-intersecting C∞superscriptCC^{\infty} smooth real analytic curves which are, in fact, real algebraic. Gustafsson [16] (after Aharonov and Shapiro [1] in the simply connected case) showed that the Schwarz function S⁢(z)SzS(z) associated to Ωnormal-Ω\Omega extends meromorphically to the double of Ωnormal-Ω\Omega. (A meromorphic function hhh on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega that extends continuously up to the boundary extends meromorphically to the double if and only if there is a meromorphic function HHH on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega that also extends continuously to the boundary such that h=H¯hnormal-¯Hh=\overline{H} on the boundary.) Since

(1.1) S⁢(z)=z¯Sznormal-¯zS(z)=\bar{z}

on the boundary, it follows that zzz extends meromorphically to the double (by defining the extension to be S⁢(z)¯normal-¯Sz\overline{S(z)} on the backside) and S⁢(z)SzS(z) extends meromorphically to the double (by defining the extension to be z¯normal-¯z\bar{z} on the backside). Gustafsson showed that the meromorphic extensions of the two functions zzz and S⁢(z)SzS(z) to the double form a primitive pair for the double, meaning that they generate the field of meromorphic functions on the double. (See Farkas and Kra [15] for the basic facts about primitive pairs and the field of meromorphic functions on the double.) Identity (1.1) allows us to see that a rational function R⁢(z,z¯)Rznormal-¯zR(z,\bar{z}) of zzz and z¯normal-¯z\bar{z} is equal to R⁢(z,S⁢(z))RzSzR(z,S(z)) on the boundary and this yields an extension of the rational function to the double as a meromorphic function. Conversely, if GGG is a meromorphic function on the double, then GGG is a rational combination of the extensions of zzz and S⁢(z)SzS(z). Since S⁢(z)=z¯Sznormal-¯zS(z)=\bar{z} on the boundary, we see that the restriction of GGG to the boundary is rational. We have seen, therefore, that the field of rational functions R⁢(z,z¯)Rznormal-¯zR(z,\bar{z}) on the boundary is precisely the set of meromorphic functions on the double restricted to the boundary. Consequently, if the rational function does not blow up on the boundary, then it is C∞superscriptCC^{\infty} smooth on the boundary. Let ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) denote the set of rational functions on the boundary without singularities on the boundary, and let ℛ⁢(Ω)ℛnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(\Omega) denote the set of meromorphic functions on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega obtained by extending functions in ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) to Ωnormal-Ω\Omega via the formula R⁢(z,z¯)=R⁢(z,S⁢(z))Rznormal-¯zRzSzR(z,\bar{z})=R(z,S(z)).

The Szegő kernel S⁢(z,w)SzwS(z,w) associated to the area quadrature domain Ωnormal-Ω\Omega extends holomorphically in zzz and anti-holomorphically in www to an open set containing Ω¯×Ω¯normal-¯normal-Ωnormal-¯normal-Ω\overline{\Omega}\times\overline{\Omega} minus the boundary diagonal. The Garabedian kernel L⁢(z,w)LzwL(z,w) extends holomorphically in zzz and holomorphically in www to an open set containing Ω¯×Ω¯normal-¯normal-Ωnormal-¯normal-Ω\overline{\Omega}\times\overline{\Omega} minus the diagonal. It has a simple pole in the zzz variable at z=wzwz=w when w∈Ωwnormal-Ωw\in\Omega is held fixed. The residue in zzz at www is 1/2⁢π12π1/2\pi. The Szegő kernel and Garabedian kernel are non-vanishing in simply connected domains, but on an nnn-connected domain, the Szegő kernel S⁢(z,w)SzwS(z,w) has n-1n1n-1 zeroes in zzz on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega for each fixed www in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega. The Garabedian kernel L⁢(z,w)LzwL(z,w), however, is non-zero if z∈Ω¯znormal-¯normal-Ωz\in\overline{\Omega} and w∈Ωwnormal-Ωw\in\Omega with z≠wzwz\neq w even in the multiply connected case. If a∈Ωanormal-Ωa\in\Omega, then neither S⁢(z,a)SzaS(z,a) nor L⁢(z,a)LzaL(z,a) vanish for zzz in the boundary. See [4] for proofs of all these facts in the spirit of this paper.

Let S0⁢(z,w)superscriptS0zwS^{0}(z,w) denote S⁢(z,w)SzwS(z,w) and let Sm⁢(z,w)superscriptSmzwS^{m}(z,w) denote (∂/∂⁡w¯)m⁢S⁢(z,w)superscriptnormal-¯wmSzw(\partial/\partial\bar{w})^{m}S(z,w). Similarly, let L0⁢(z,w)superscriptL0zwL^{0}(z,w) denote L⁢(z,w)LzwL(z,w) and let Lm⁢(z,w)superscriptLmzwL^{m}(z,w) denote (∂/∂⁡w)m⁢L⁢(z,w)superscriptwmLzw(\partial/\partial w)^{m}L(z,w). The Szegő span is the complex linear span 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} of all functions h⁢(z)hzh(z) of the form h⁢(z)=Sm⁢(z,a)hzsuperscriptSmzah(z)=S^{m}(z,a) as aaa ranges over Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and mmm ranges over all non-negative integers. The Garabedian span is the complex linear span ℒℒ\mathcal{L} of all functions H⁢(z)HzH(z) of the form H⁢(z)=Lm⁢(z,a)HzsuperscriptLmzaH(z)=L^{m}(z,a) as aaa ranges over Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and mmm ranges over all non-negative integers. The Szegő plus Garabedian span is the set 𝒮+ℒ𝒮ℒ\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L} of all sums h+HhHh+H where hhh is in the Szegő span and HHH is in the Garabedian span. We will often shorten our notation by writing Sam⁢(z)=Sm⁢(z,a)superscriptsubscriptSamzsuperscriptSmzaS_{a}^{m}(z)=S^{m}(z,a) and Lam⁢(z)=Lm⁢(z,a)superscriptsubscriptLamzsuperscriptLmzaL_{a}^{m}(z)=L^{m}(z,a), and we emphasize here that the unadorned S⁢(z)SzS(z) will always stand for the Schwarz function. Note that, because L⁢(z,a)LzaL(z,a) has a singular part that is a non-zero constant times (z-a)-1superscriptza1(z-a)^{-1}, the singular part of LamsuperscriptsubscriptLamL_{a}^{m} is a non-zero constant times (z-a)-(m+1)superscriptzam1(z-a)^{-(m+1)}.

To have a proper feeling for the Szegő and Garabedian spans, we mention here that the Szegő span is a dense subspace of the L2superscriptL2L^{2}-Hardy space and the Garabedian span is a dense subspace of the orthogonal complement to the L2superscriptL2L^{2}-Hardy space in L2⁢(b⁢Ω)superscriptL2bnormal-ΩL^{2}(b\Omega). Hence 𝒮+ℒ𝒮ℒ\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L} is dense in L2superscriptL2L^{2} of the boundary. Let A∞⁢(Ω)superscriptAnormal-ΩA^{\infty}(\Omega) denote the space of holomorphic functions on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega in C∞⁢(Ω¯)superscriptCnormal-¯normal-ΩC^{\infty}(\overline{\Omega}). The Szegő span is also a dense subspace of A∞⁢(Ω)superscriptAnormal-ΩA^{\infty}(\Omega) and the Garabedian span is a dense subspace of the orthogonal complement to the L2superscriptL2L^{2}-Hardy space in the topology of C∞⁢(b⁢Ω)superscriptCbnormal-ΩC^{\infty}(b\Omega). Hence 𝒮+ℒ𝒮ℒ\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L} is dense in C∞superscriptCC^{\infty} on the boundary. (See [3] and [4] for proofs of these facts in the more general smooth domain case. The density of the space of rational functions on the boundary of an area quadrature domain in C∞superscriptCC^{\infty} of the boundary is also proved in the last section of [9].)

Let T⁢(z)TzT(z) denote the complex unit tangent vector function defined on the boundary of Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and pointing in the direction of the standard orientation of the boundary. A very important identity at the heart of much of this paper is the relationship between the Szegő kernel and the Garabedian kernel,

(1.2) Sa⁢(z)¯=1i⁢La⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z),normal-¯subscriptSaz1isubscriptLazTz\overline{S_{a}(z)}=\frac{1}{i}L_{a}(z)T(z),

which holds for z∈b⁢Ωzbnormal-Ωz\in b\Omega and a∈Ωanormal-Ωa\in\Omega. We may differentiate this identity with respect to aaa to obtain

(1.3) Sam⁢(z)¯=1i⁢Lam⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z).normal-¯superscriptsubscriptSamz1isuperscriptsubscriptLamzTz\overline{S_{a}^{m}(z)}=\frac{1}{i}L_{a}^{m}(z)T(z).

If Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is a double quadrature domain, then all the properties above hold plus the property (proved by Gustafsson in [17]) that T⁢(z)TzT(z) extends to the double as a meromorphic function. Consequently, identities (1.2) and (1.3) show that the functions SamsuperscriptsubscriptSamS_{a}^{m} and LamsuperscriptsubscriptLamL_{a}^{m} also extend to the double for each aaa in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and m≥0m0m\geq 0.

With these preliminaries behind us, we can state our main results. We call the first result the Basic Decomposition.

Theorem 1.1.

Given a point aaa in an area quadrature domain Ωnormal-Ω\Omega,

Sa⁢ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)=𝒮+ℒ,subscriptSaℛbnormal-Ω𝒮ℒS_{a}{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega)=\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L},

where the function spaces on the right are understood to be restricted to the boundary. On a double quadrature domain,

ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)=𝒮+ℒ.ℛbnormal-Ω𝒮ℒ{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega)=\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L}.

We will prove this theorem in the next section, where it will be seen that the coefficients that appear in the decompositions are determined by the principal parts of two meromorphic functions. We remark here that, because the functions on the left hand side of the equalities in Theorem 1.1 extend meromorphically to Ωnormal-Ω\Omega via the R⁢(z,z¯)=R⁢(z,S⁢(z))Rznormal-¯zRzSzR(z,\bar{z})=R(z,S(z)) substitution, and the functions on the right also extend, we may also state the following result.

Theorem 1.2.

Given a point aaa in an area quadrature domain Ωnormal-Ω\Omega,

Sa⁢ℛ⁢(Ω)=𝒮+ℒ.subscriptSaℛnormal-Ω𝒮ℒS_{a}{\mathcal{R}}(\Omega)=\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L}.

On a double quadrature domain,

ℛ⁢(Ω)=𝒮+ℒ.ℛnormal-Ω𝒮ℒ{\mathcal{R}}(\Omega)=\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L}.

We will show how the decomposition in Theorem 1.1 can be used to solve the Dirichlet problem in §3. We will consider the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map in §4, and finally the Neumann problem in §6.

Note that functions in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} are holomorphic on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and functions in ℒℒ\mathcal{L} have poles. Hence, it follows as a corollary to Theorem 1.2 that the class of holomorphic functions on a double quadrature domain which extend meromorphically to the double and which have no singularities on the boundary is exactly equal to the Szegő span.

Since 𝒮+ℒ𝒮ℒ\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L} is an orthogonal sum, the following theorem is an easy consequence of Theorem 1.1.

Theorem 1.3.

Let aaa be a point in an area quadrature domain Ωnormal-Ω\Omega. The Szegő projection associated to Ωnormal-Ω\Omega maps Sa⁢ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)subscriptSaℛbnormal-ΩS_{a}{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) onto the Szegő span. If Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is a double quadrature domain, it maps ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) onto the Szegő span.

The results of the next section will therefore show that the Szegő projection of a rational function can be computed via rather straightforward algebra on quadrature domains.

Before we start proving the decompositions, we mention that related results hold for the Bergman kernel and span. Let B⁢(z,w)BzwB(z,w) denote the Bergman kernel associated to a bounded area quadrature domain and let Λ⁢(z,w)normal-Λzw\Lambda(z,w) denote the complimentary kernel (or conjugate kernel) to the Bergman kernel (see [4, p. 134] for the definition and basic properties of Λ⁢(z,w)normal-Λzw\Lambda(z,w)). We may define the Bergman span ℬℬ\mathcal{B} and the complimentary kernel span Λnormal-Λ\mathnormal{\Lambda} exactly as we defined the Szegő span and Garabedian span. Let ℛ′⁢(Ω)superscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}^{\prime}(\Omega) denote the set of meromorphic functions on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega that are derivatives of functions in ℛ⁢(Ω)ℛnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(\Omega).

Theorem 1.4.

On a simply connected area quadrature domain Ωnormal-Ω\Omega,

ℛ′⁢(Ω)=ℬ+Λ.superscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ωℬnormal-Λ{\mathcal{R}}^{\prime}(\Omega)=\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda}.

On a multiply connected area quadrature domain, ℛ′⁢(Ω)superscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}^{\prime}(\Omega) is comprised of the functions in ℬ+Λℬnormal-Λ\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda} with vanishing periods.

We will explain in §5 why a major part of the proof of Theorem 1.4 should be attributed to Björn Gustafsson.

We remark, that since all non-zero functions in the space Λnormal-Λ\mathnormal{\Lambda} have poles in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega, a corollary of Theorem 1.4 is that, on an area quadrature domain, a function in ℛ′⁢(Ω)superscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}^{\prime}(\Omega) without singularities in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega must be in the Bergman span. This result will allow us to characterize the image of the rational functions under the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map of an area quadrature domain.

Call the map that takes Dirichlet problem boundary data to the normal derivative of the solution to the Dirichlet problem the D-to-N map.

Theorem 1.5.

On an area quadrature domain, the D-to-N map takes ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) into ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT\mathcal{B}T+\overline{\mathcal{B}T}. On a double quadrature domain, ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT\mathcal{B}T+\overline{\mathcal{B}T} is contained in ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) and so the D-to-N map takes takes ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) into itself.

More can be said in case the quadrature domains are simply connected.

Theorem 1.6.

On a simply connected area quadrature domain, the D-to-N map takes ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) onto ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT\mathcal{B}T+\overline{\mathcal{B}T}.

We will show that, on an area quadrature domain, the decomposition ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT\mathcal{B}T+\overline{\mathcal{B}T} in Theorem 1.5 uniquely determines the functions in the Bergman span appearing in the sum, as made precise in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.7.

On an area quadrature domain, functions in ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT\mathcal{B}T+\overline{\mathcal{B}T} are represented as κ1⁢T+κ2⁢T¯subscriptκ1Tnormal-¯subscriptκ2T\kappa_{1}T+\overline{\kappa_{2}T} by uniquely determined elements κ1subscriptκ1\kappa_{1} and κ2subscriptκ2\kappa_{2} in the Bergman span.

Results like this will allow us to consider a one-sided inverse to the D-to-N map in the setting of Theorem 1.6 that is defined in rather explicit terms (see Theorem 5.1 in §5).

2. The basic decomposition in area quadrature domains

Suppose that Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is a bounded area quadrature domain and suppose ϕ⁢(z)=R⁢(z,z¯)ϕzRznormal-¯z\phi(z)=R(z,\bar{z}) is a rational function of zzz and z¯normal-¯z\bar{z} without singularities on b⁢Ωbnormal-Ωb\Omega. We will now explain how to produce a finite decomposition of ϕϕ\phi on the boundary in terms of the Szegő kernel and the Garabedian kernel that can be thought of as an analogue of a “partial fractions decomposition” on the boundary. The decomposition will allow us to solve the Dirichlet problem with rational boundary data in finite terms.

Pick a point aaa in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega. Notice that

Sa⁢(z)⁢ϕ⁢(z)=Sa⁢(z)⁢R⁢(z,z¯)=Sa⁢(z)⁢R⁢(z,S⁢(z))subscriptSazϕzsubscriptSazRznormal-¯zsubscriptSazRzSzS_{a}(z)\phi(z)=S_{a}(z)R(z,\bar{z})=S_{a}(z)R(z,S(z))

on the boundary, and this defines a meromorphic extension GGG of Sa⁢ϕsubscriptSaϕS_{a}\phi to Ωnormal-Ω\Omega. We now subtract off the unique linear combination λλ\lambda of the functions of the form LbkmsubscriptsuperscriptLmsubscriptbkL^{m}_{b_{k}} to remove the poles of the meromorphic function GGG on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega. We will show that

h⁢(z):=G⁢(z)-λ⁢(z)assignhzGzλzh(z):=G(z)-\lambda(z)

is a function in the Szegő span 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}. Indeed, if we pair hhh with a function ggg in the dense subset of the Hardy space consisting of functions in A∞⁢(Ω)superscriptAnormal-ΩA^{\infty}(\Omega), and note that functions of the form LbkmsubscriptsuperscriptLmsubscriptbkL^{m}_{b_{k}} are orthogonal to the Hardy space, we may use the identity S⁢(z)=z¯Sznormal-¯zS(z)=\bar{z} and identity (1.2) to see that

⟨g,h⟩=∫z∈b⁢Ωg⁢(z)⁢Sa⁢(z)⁢R⁢(z,S⁢(z))¯ d⁢s=-i⁢∫z∈b⁢Ωg⁢(z)⁢La⁢(z)⁢R⁢(S⁢(z)¯,z¯)¯ d⁢z,formulae-sequenceghsubscriptzbnormal-Ωgznormal-¯subscriptSazRzSzdsisubscriptzbnormal-ΩgzsubscriptLaznormal-¯Rnormal-¯Sznormal-¯zdz\langle g,h\rangle=\int_{z\in b\Omega}g(z)\,\overline{S_{a}(z)R(z,S(z))}\ ds=-% i\int_{z\in b\Omega}g(z)L_{a}(z)\,\overline{R(\,\overline{S(z)}\,,\bar{z})}\ dz,

and the residue theorem shows that this last integral yields a finite linear combination of values of ggg and its derivatives at finitely many points. Hence, hhh is equal to the linear combination of the functions SakmsubscriptsuperscriptSmsubscriptakS^{m}_{a_{k}} which would have the same effect when paired with ggg.

We have shown that there are finitely many points ansubscriptana_{n} and bnsubscriptbnb_{n} in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and positive integers NSsubscriptNSN_{S}, MSsubscriptMSM_{S}, NLsubscriptNLN_{L}, and MLsubscriptMLM_{L} such that

(2.1) Sa⁢(z)⁢R⁢(z,z¯)=∑n=1NS∑m=0MSAn⁢m⁢Sanm⁢(z)+∑n=1NL∑m=0MLBn⁢m⁢Lbnm⁢(z)subscriptSazRznormal-¯zsuperscriptsubscriptn1subscriptNSsuperscriptsubscriptm0subscriptMSsubscriptAnmsuperscriptsubscriptSsubscriptanmzsuperscriptsubscriptn1subscriptNLsuperscriptsubscriptm0subscriptMLsubscriptBnmsuperscriptsubscriptLsubscriptbnmzS_{a}(z)R(z,\bar{z})=\sum_{n=1}^{N_{S}}\sum_{m=0}^{M_{S}}A_{nm}S_{a_{n}}^{m}(z% )+\sum_{n=1}^{N_{L}}\sum_{m=0}^{M_{L}}B_{nm}L_{b_{n}}^{m}(z)

on the boundary of Ωnormal-Ω\Omega.

We remark here that, just as in the method of undetermined coefficients, the coefficients and points in the decomposition (2.1) are uniquely determined by the principal parts of meromorphic functions with finitely many poles. Indeed the coefficients Bn⁢msubscriptBnmB_{nm} and the points bnsubscriptbnb_{n} were chosen so that the principal parts of the sum λλ\lambda match the principal parts of Sa⁢(z)⁢R⁢(z,S⁢(z))subscriptSazRzSzS_{a}(z)R(z,S(z)). If we multiply the decomposition by T⁢(z)TzT(z) and use identities (1.2) and (1.3), and note that R⁢(z,z¯)=R⁢(S⁢(z)¯,z¯)Rznormal-¯zRnormal-¯Sznormal-¯zR(z,\bar{z})=R(\,\overline{S(z)}\,,\bar{z}) on the boundary, we obtain after conjugation

(2.2) La⁢(z)⁢R⁢(S⁢(z)¯,z¯)¯=∑n=1NS∑m=0MSAn⁢m¯⁢Lanm⁢(z)+∑n=1NL∑m=0MLBn⁢m¯⁢Sbnm⁢(z),subscriptLaznormal-¯Rnormal-¯Sznormal-¯zsuperscriptsubscriptn1subscriptNSsuperscriptsubscriptm0subscriptMSnormal-¯subscriptAnmsuperscriptsubscriptLsubscriptanmzsuperscriptsubscriptn1subscriptNLsuperscriptsubscriptm0subscriptMLnormal-¯subscriptBnmsuperscriptsubscriptSsubscriptbnmzL_{a}(z)\overline{R(\,\overline{S(z)}\,,\bar{z})}=\sum_{n=1}^{N_{S}}\sum_{m=0}% ^{M_{S}}\overline{A_{nm}}\,L_{a_{n}}^{m}(z)+\sum_{n=1}^{N_{L}}\sum_{m=0}^{M_{L% }}\overline{B_{nm}}\,S_{b_{n}}^{m}(z),

and so we see that the coefficients An⁢msubscriptAnmA_{nm} and the points ansubscriptana_{n} are determined by the principal parts of La⁢(z)⁢R⁢(S⁢(z)¯,z¯)¯subscriptLaznormal-¯Rnormal-¯Sznormal-¯zL_{a}(z)\overline{R(\,\overline{S(z)}\,,\bar{z})} in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega.

We have shown that SasubscriptSaS_{a} times a rational function is in the Szegő plus Garabedian span when restricted to the boundary. To finish the proof of Theorem 1.1 for area quadrature domains, we need to show that a function in 𝒮+ℒ𝒮ℒ\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L} divided by SasubscriptSaS_{a}, when restricted to the boundary, is rational and without singularities on the boundary. If we divide a function in 𝒮+ℒ𝒮ℒ\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L} by SasubscriptSaS_{a}, we obtain a sum of functions of the form Sanm/SasuperscriptsubscriptSsubscriptanmsubscriptSaS_{a_{n}}^{m}/S_{a} and Lanm/SasuperscriptsubscriptLsubscriptanmsubscriptSaL_{a_{n}}^{m}/S_{a}. Such functions extend to the double of Ωnormal-Ω\Omega as meromorphic functions because identities (1.2) and 1.3 show that they are equal to the conjugates of Lanm/LasuperscriptsubscriptLsubscriptanmsubscriptLaL_{a_{n}}^{m}/L_{a} and Sanm/LasuperscriptsubscriptSsubscriptanmsubscriptLaS_{a_{n}}^{m}/L_{a}, respectively, on the boundary. Since these functions extend to the double and do not have singularities on the boundary, they are therefore rational combinations of zzz and S⁢(z)SzS(z), which when restricted to the boundary, are rational functions of zzz and z¯normal-¯z\bar{z} without singularities on the boundary. This completes the proof of the part of Theorem 1.1 about area quadrature domains.

We remark that the space of functions on the boundary given by SasubscriptSaS_{a} times a rational function is easily seen to be independent of the point aaa since quotients of the form Sa/SbsubscriptSasubscriptSbS_{a}/S_{b} extend meromorphically to the double, and are therefore rational on the boundary.

On a double quadrature domain, SasubscriptSaS_{a} extends to the double as a meromorphic function and has no singularities on the boundary (see [11]). Therefore Sa⁢ℛ=ℛsubscriptSaℛℛS_{a}\mathcal{R}=\mathcal{R} and the proof of Theorem 1.1 is complete.

3. Using the decomposition to solve the Dirichlet problem

We first assume that Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is a simply connected area quadrature domain. We will now show how the decomposition (2.1) produces a simple and explicit solution to the Dirichlet problem with rational boundary data R⁢(z,z¯)Rznormal-¯zR(z,\bar{z}). Recall that SasubscriptSaS_{a} and LasubscriptLaL_{a} are non-vanishing on Ω¯normal-¯normal-Ω\overline{\Omega} and extend holomorphically past the boundary in case Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is simply connected. Notice that if we divide the decomposition (2.1) by SasubscriptSaS_{a}, then we decompose our boundary data R⁢(z,z¯)Rznormal-¯zR(z,\bar{z}) into a finite sum of functions of the form Sbm/SasuperscriptsubscriptSbmsubscriptSaS_{b}^{m}/S_{a} and Lbm/SasuperscriptsubscriptLbmsubscriptSaL_{b}^{m}/S_{a}. The functions Sbm/SasuperscriptsubscriptSbmsubscriptSaS_{b}^{m}/S_{a} extend holomorphically to Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and are smooth up to the boundary. Identities (1.2) and (1.3) reveal that Lbm/SasuperscriptsubscriptLbmsubscriptSaL_{b}^{m}/S_{a} is equal to the conjugate of Sbm/LasuperscriptsubscriptSbmsubscriptLaS_{b}^{m}/L_{a} on the boundary and therefore these functions extend antiholomorphically to Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and are smooth up to the boundary. (Note that the simple pole of LasubscriptLaL_{a} at aaa gives rise to a zero of the quotient at aaa.) Consequently, we can read off the conclusion of the following theorem.

Theorem 3.1.

The solution to the Dirichlet problem on a simply connected area quadrature domain with rational boundary data R⁢(z,z¯)Rznormal-¯zR(z,\bar{z}) can be read off from the basic decomposition of Sa⁢(z)⁢R⁢(z,z¯)subscriptSazRznormal-¯zS_{a}(z)R(z,\bar{z}) and is of the form h+H¯hnormal-¯Hh+\overline{H} where both hhh and HHH are sums of quotients that extend holomorphically to Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and meromorphically to the double. In fact, hhh is a quotient of the form σ1/Sasubscriptσ1subscriptSa\sigma_{1}/S_{a} and HHH is a quotient of the form σ2/Lasubscriptσ2subscriptLa\sigma_{2}/L_{a} where σjsubscriptσj\sigma_{j}, j=1,2j12j=1,2, are functions in the Szegő span.

Note that meromorphic functions on the double are generated by the meromorphic extensions of zzz and S⁢(z)SzS(z) to the double, and that S⁢(z)SzS(z) is algebraic. Thus, we have given an alternate way of looking at Ebenfelt’s theorem [13] about the algebraicity of the solution to the Dirichlet problem with rational boundary data on simply connected area quadrature domains (see also [10] for more about this fascinating subject).

We may repeat much of the same reasoning in case Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is an nnn-connected area quadrature domain, taking into account that SasubscriptSaS_{a} has n-1n1n-1 zeroes. We may choose the point aaa so that the n-1n1n-1 zeroes of SasubscriptSaS_{a} are distinct and simple (see [4, p. 105]). Let a1,…,an-1subscripta1normal-…subscriptan1a_{1},\dots,a_{n-1} denote these zeroes. Let G⁢(z,w)GzwG(z,w) denote the classical Green’s function associated to Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and write Gw0⁢(z)=G⁢(z,w)superscriptsubscriptGw0zGzwG_{w}^{0}(z)=G(z,w). For m≥1m1m\geq 1, define

Gwm⁢(z):=∂m∂⁡wm⁢G⁢(z,w) and Gwm¯⁢(z):=∂m∂⁡w¯m⁢G⁢(z,w).formulae-sequenceassignsuperscriptsubscriptGwmzsuperscriptmsuperscriptwmGzwandassignsuperscriptsubscriptGwnormal-¯mzsuperscriptmsuperscriptnormal-¯wmGzwG_{w}^{\,m}(z):=\frac{\partial^{m}}{\partial w^{m}}G(z,w)\quad\text{and}\quad G% _{w}^{\,\bar{m}}(z):=\frac{\partial^{m}}{\partial\bar{w}^{m}}G(z,w).

Note that, as a function of zzz, Gbm⁢(z)superscriptsubscriptGbmzG_{b}^{m}(z) has a singular part at b∈Ωbnormal-Ωb\in\Omega that is a non-zero constant times 1/(z-b)m1superscriptzbm1/(z-b)^{m}, is harmonic in zzz on Ω-{b}normal-Ωb\Omega-\{b\}, extends continuously to the boundary and vanishes on the boundary. Similarly, Gbm¯⁢(z)superscriptsubscriptGbnormal-¯mzG_{b}^{\bar{m}}(z) has a singular part that is a non-zero constant times the conjugate of 1/(z-b)m1superscriptzbm1/(z-b)^{m}, is harmonic in zzz on Ω-{b}normal-Ωb\Omega-\{b\}, extends continuously to the boundary and vanishes on the boundary.

To solve the Dirichlet problem on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega, given rational boundary data R⁢(z,z¯)Rznormal-¯zR(z,\bar{z}), as in the simply connected case, the decomposition (2.1) yields

R⁢(z,z¯)=h+H¯Rznormal-¯zhnormal-¯HR(z,\bar{z})=h+\overline{H}

on the boundary, where

h=σ1⁢(z)Sa⁢(z)   and   H=σ2⁢(z)La⁢(z),formulae-sequencehsubscriptσ1zsubscriptSaz and Hsubscriptσ2zsubscriptLazh=\frac{\sigma_{1}(z)}{S_{a}(z)}\qquad\text{ and }\qquad H=\frac{\sigma_{2}(z)% }{L_{a}(z)},

and where σ1subscriptσ1\sigma_{1} and σ2subscriptσ2\sigma_{2} are in the Szegő span. Note that hhh and HHH extend smoothly to the boundary, that HHH is holomorphic on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega because LasubscriptLaL_{a} is non-vanishing on Ω¯-{a}normal-¯normal-Ωa\overline{\Omega}-\{a\} and the pole of LasubscriptLaL_{a} creates a zero of HHH at aaa, but hhh is perhaps only meromorphic since it may have simple poles at some or all of the zeroes of SasubscriptSaS_{a}. However, by subtracting off appropriate constants times Gak1superscriptsubscriptGsubscriptak1G_{a_{k}}^{1} for each of the zeroes aksubscriptaka_{k} to remove the simple poles, noting that these functions vanish on the boundary, we obtain the harmonic extension of our boundary data to Ωnormal-Ω\Omega in the form

(3.1) h+H¯+∑k=1n-1ck⁢Gak1,hnormal-¯Hsuperscriptsubscriptk1n1subscriptcksuperscriptsubscriptGsubscriptak1h+\overline{H}+\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}c_{k}G_{a_{k}}^{1},

where hhh and HHH extend meromorphically to the double, and hence are rational combinations of zzz and the Schwarz function S⁢(z)SzS(z). Consequently, we have an alternate way to that given in [9] to see that the solution to the Dirichlet problem with rational boundary data is algebraic, modulo an n-1n1n-1 dimensional subspace.

4. The Dirichlet-to-Neumann map

We now continue the line of thought of the last section and consider the implications for the D-to-N map for rational boundary data on an area quadrature domain Ωnormal-Ω\Omega. It is shown in [4, p. 134-135] that, if w∈Ωwnormal-Ωw\in\Omega is held fixed, the normal derivative (∂/∂⁡nz)subscriptnz(\partial/\partial n_{z}) of Gw0⁢(z)superscriptsubscriptGw0zG_{w}^{0}(z) with respect to zzz is given by

∂∂⁡nz⁢Gw0⁢(z)=-i⁢T⁢(z)⁢∂∂⁡z⁢Gw0⁢(z)+i⁢T⁢(z)¯⁢∂∂⁡z⁢Gw0⁢(z)¯.subscriptnzsuperscriptsubscriptGw0ziTzzsuperscriptsubscriptGw0zinormal-¯Tznormal-¯zsuperscriptsubscriptGw0z\frac{\partial}{\partial n_{z}}G_{w}^{0}(z)=-iT(z)\frac{\partial}{\partial z}G% _{w}^{0}(z)+i\,\overline{T(z)}\,\overline{\frac{\partial}{\partial z}G_{w}^{0}% (z)}.

We remark here that it is also shown there that this expression can be further manipulated to yield two more expressions for the same normal derivative,

∂∂⁡nz⁢Gw0⁢(z)=-2⁢i⁢T⁢(z)⁢∂∂⁡z⁢Gw0⁢(z)=2⁢i⁢T⁢(z)¯⁢∂∂⁡z⁢Gw0⁢(z)¯.subscriptnzsuperscriptsubscriptGw0z2iTzzsuperscriptsubscriptGw0z2inormal-¯Tznormal-¯zsuperscriptsubscriptGw0z\frac{\partial}{\partial n_{z}}G_{w}^{0}(z)=-2iT(z)\frac{\partial}{\partial z}% G_{w}^{0}(z)=2i\,\overline{T(z)}\,\overline{\frac{\partial}{\partial z}G_{w}^{% 0}(z)}.

Although these expressions are shorter and simpler, we will have reason to prefer the longer form. Hence, for m≥1m1m\geq 1, the normal derivative of Gwm⁢(z)superscriptsubscriptGwmzG_{w}^{m}(z) is given by

(4.1) ∂∂⁡nz⁢Gwm⁢(z)=-i⁢T⁢(z)⁢∂∂⁡z⁢Gwm⁢(z)+i⁢T⁢(z)¯⁢∂∂⁡z⁢Gwm¯⁢(z)¯,subscriptnzsuperscriptsubscriptGwmziTzzsuperscriptsubscriptGwmzinormal-¯Tznormal-¯zsuperscriptsubscriptGwnormal-¯mz\frac{\partial}{\partial n_{z}}G_{w}^{m}(z)=-iT(z)\frac{\partial}{\partial z}G% _{w}^{m}(z)+i\,\overline{T(z)}\overline{\frac{\partial}{\partial z}G_{w}^{\bar% {m}}(z)},

and the alternative expressions above yield

∂∂⁡nz⁢Gwm⁢(z)=-2⁢i⁢T⁢(z)⁢∂∂⁡z⁢Gwm⁢(z)=2⁢i⁢T⁢(z)¯⁢∂∂⁡z⁢Gwm¯⁢(z)¯.subscriptnzsuperscriptsubscriptGwmz2iTzzsuperscriptsubscriptGwmz2inormal-¯Tznormal-¯zsuperscriptsubscriptGwnormal-¯mz\frac{\partial}{\partial n_{z}}G_{w}^{m}(z)=-2iT(z)\frac{\partial}{\partial z}% G_{w}^{m}(z)=2i\,\overline{T(z)}\,\overline{\frac{\partial}{\partial z}G_{w}^{% \bar{m}}(z)}.

It is shown in [4, p. 77, 134-135] that the normal derivative of the solution to the Dirichlet problem given by equation (3.1) is

-i⁢h′⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z)+i⁢H′⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z)¯-i⁢T⁢(z)⁢∑k=1n-1ck⁢∂∂⁡z⁢Gak1⁢(z)+i⁢T⁢(z)¯⁢∑k=1n-1ck⁢∂∂⁡z⁢Gak1¯⁢(z)¯.isuperscripthnormal-′zTzinormal-¯superscriptHnormal-′zTziTzsuperscriptsubscriptk1n1subscriptckzsuperscriptsubscriptGsubscriptak1zinormal-¯Tzsuperscriptsubscriptk1n1subscriptcknormal-¯zsuperscriptsubscriptGsubscriptaknormal-¯1z-ih^{\prime}(z)T(z)+i\,\overline{H^{\prime}(z)T(z)}-iT(z)\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}c_{k}% \frac{\partial}{\partial z}G_{a_{k}}^{1}(z)+i\overline{T(z)}\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}c_% {k}\overline{\frac{\partial}{\partial z}G_{a_{k}}^{\bar{1}}(z)}.

But, for w∈Ωwnormal-Ωw\in\Omega, the Bergman kernel B⁢(z,w)BzwB(z,w) is related to the Green’s function via

B⁢(z,w)=-2π⁢∂2∂⁡z⁢∂⁡w¯⁢G⁢(z,w)Bzw2πsuperscript2znormal-¯wGzwB(z,w)=-\frac{2}{\pi}\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z\partial\bar{w}}G(z,w)

and the complimentary kernel Λ⁢(z,w)normal-Λzw\Lambda(z,w) to the Bergman kernel is given by definition as

Λ⁢(z,w)=-2π⁢∂2∂⁡z⁢∂⁡w⁢G⁢(z,w).normal-Λzw2πsuperscript2zwGzw\Lambda(z,w)=-\frac{2}{\pi}\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial z\partial w}G(z,w).

(See [4, p. 134] for these identities and the basic properties of Λ⁢(z,w)normal-Λzw\Lambda(z,w).) Consequently, the last formula for the normal derivative can be rewritten as

(4.2) -i⁢h′⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z)+i⁢H′⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z)¯+π⁢i2⁢T⁢(z)⁢∑k=1n-1ck⁢Λ⁢(z,ak)-π⁢i2⁢T⁢(z)¯⁢∑k=1n-1ck⁢B⁢(z,ak)¯.isuperscripthnormal-′zTzinormal-¯superscriptHnormal-′zTzπi2Tzsuperscriptsubscriptk1n1subscriptcknormal-Λzsubscriptakπi2normal-¯Tzsuperscriptsubscriptk1n1subscriptcknormal-¯Bzsubscriptak-ih^{\prime}(z)T(z)+i\,\overline{H^{\prime}(z)T(z)}+\frac{\pi i}{2}T(z)\sum_{k% =1}^{n-1}c_{k}\Lambda(z,a_{k})-\frac{\pi i}{2}\,\overline{T(z)}\,\sum_{k=1}^{n% -1}c_{k}\overline{B(z,a_{k})}.

It is shown in [7] that, on an area quadrature domain, if a meromorphic function ggg extends meromorphically to the double, then g′superscriptgnormal-′g^{\prime} also extends meromorphically to the double. It is shown in [7] that the Bergman kernel extends meromorphically to the double on an area quadrature domain. We will prove momentarily that Λ⁢(z,ak)normal-Λzsubscriptak\Lambda(z,a_{k}) also extends meromorphically to the double as a function of zzz. Hence, we have expressed the normal derivative of the solution to the Dirichlet problem as g⁢T+G⁢T¯gTnormal-¯GTgT+\overline{GT} where ggg and GGG are meromorphic functions on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega that extend meromorphically to the double, and are consequently rational combinations of zzz and S⁢(z)SzS(z). When we restrict to the boundary, we conclude that ggg and GGG are rational functions of zzz and z¯normal-¯z\bar{z} on the boundary. It is shown in [7] that, on an area quadrature domain, the function T2superscriptT2T^{2} extends to the double as a meromorphic function. Hence, the Neumann boundary data of the solution to the Dirichlet problem with rational boundary data is a sum of a rational function times the square root of a rational function plus the conjugate of such expressions. On a double quadrature domain, the function TTT itself extends meromorphically to the double, and in this case, we may state that the D-to-N map sends rational functions of zzz and z¯normal-¯z\bar{z} to rational functions of zzz and z¯normal-¯z\bar{z}. In the next section, we consider which rational functions appear in the range of the D-to-N map in this manner.

We now give the promised proof that Λ⁢(z,a)normal-Λza\Lambda(z,a) extends meromorphically in zzz to the double for fixed a∈Ωanormal-Ωa\in\Omega when Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is an area quadrature domain. The Bergman kernel B⁢(z,a)BzaB(z,a) is related to Λ⁢(z,a)normal-Λza\Lambda(z,a) via the identity

(4.3) B⁢(z,a)⁢T⁢(z)=-Λ⁢(z,a)⁢T⁢(z)¯BzaTznormal-¯normal-ΛzaTzB(z,a)T(z)=-\overline{\Lambda(z,a)T(z)}

for zzz in the boundary. Since Λ⁢(z,a)normal-Λza\Lambda(z,a) is equal to minus the conjugate of the quantity B⁢(z,a)BzaB(z,a) times T⁢(z)2Tsuperscriptz2T(z)^{2} on the boundary, and since both of these functions extend meromorphically to the double, and are therefore rational functions of zzz and S⁢(z)=z¯Sznormal-¯zS(z)=\bar{z} on the boundary, it follows that Λ⁢(z,a)normal-Λza\Lambda(z,a) extends meromorphically to the double and is equal to a rational combination of zzz and z¯normal-¯z\bar{z} on the boundary.

The identity (4.3) or the simpler expressions for the normal derivatives of the Green’s functions could be used to simplify (4.2) to read

(4.4) -i⁢h′⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z)+i⁢H′⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z)¯+π⁢i⁢T⁢(z)⁢∑k=1n-1ck⁢Λ⁢(z,ak),isuperscripthnormal-′zTzinormal-¯superscriptHnormal-′zTzπiTzsuperscriptsubscriptk1n1subscriptcknormal-Λzsubscriptak-ih^{\prime}(z)T(z)+i\,\overline{H^{\prime}(z)T(z)}+\pi iT(z)\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}c% _{k}\Lambda(z,a_{k}),

or even

(4.5) -i⁢h′⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z)+i⁢H′⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z)¯-π⁢i⁢T⁢(z)¯⁢∑k=1n-1ck⁢B⁢(z,ak)¯,isuperscripthnormal-′zTzinormal-¯superscriptHnormal-′zTzπinormal-¯Tzsuperscriptsubscriptk1n1subscriptcknormal-¯Bzsubscriptak-ih^{\prime}(z)T(z)+i\,\overline{H^{\prime}(z)T(z)}-\pi i\,\overline{T(z)}\sum% _{k=1}^{n-1}c_{k}\overline{B(z,a_{k})},

but we prefer (4.2) because the poles of the Λ⁢(z,ak)normal-Λzsubscriptak\Lambda(z,a_{k}) terms exactly cancel the poles of h′superscripthnormal-′h^{\prime} the way we have chosen the coefficients, and therefore the normal derivative is in fact expressed as g⁢T+G⁢T¯gTnormal-¯GTgT+\overline{GT} where ggg and GGG are holomorphic functions on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega that extend smoothly to the boundary, and that extend meromorphically to the double. We will have more to say on this subject later when we prove Theorem 1.5.

An interesting consequence of equations (4.4) and  (4.5) is that they imply that certain period matrices are non-singular.

Theorem 4.1.

Suppose that the zeroes a1,…⁢an-1subscripta1normal-…subscriptan1a_{1},\dots a_{n-1} of the Szegő kernel associated to a point aaa in an nnn-connected area quadrature domain Ωnormal-Ω\Omega are simple. Then the matrix of periods associated to the functions K⁢(z,ak)KzsubscriptakK(z,a_{k}), k=1,…,n-1k1normal-…n1k=1,\dots,n-1 is non-singular. So is the matrix of periods associated to the functions Λ⁢(z,ak)normal-Λzsubscriptak\Lambda(z,a_{k}), k=1,…,n-1k1normal-…n1k=1,\dots,n-1.

We remark that it was proved in [8] that, if Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is nnn connected, then there exist n-1n1n-1 points b1,b2,…,bn-1subscriptb1subscriptb2normal-…subscriptbn1b_{1},b_{2},\dots,b_{n-1} in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega such that the period matrix of K⁢(z,bk)KzsubscriptbkK(z,b_{k}) is non-singular. It is also interesting to note that, because of the way the zeroes of the Szegő kernel and the periods of the functions in Theorem 4.1 transform under conformal changes of variables, and because smoothly bounded nnn-connected domains are conformally equivalent to an area quadrature domain via Gustafsson’s theorem [16], Theorem 4.1 can be seen to hold for general bounded smooth nnn-connected domains as well.

To prove Theorem 4.1, note that because the rational functions are dense in C∞⁢(b⁢Ω)superscriptCbnormal-ΩC^{\infty}(b\Omega), we may approximate a harmonic measure function ωksubscriptωk\omega_{k} which is harmonic on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and equal to one on the kkk-th boundary curve of the n-1n1n-1 inner boundary curves and equal to zero on the other boundary curves. The normal derivative of the solution to the Dirichlet problem with this rational boundary data is given by equation (4.4), and it can be made as close in C∞⁢(b⁢Ω)superscriptCbnormal-ΩC^{\infty}(b\Omega) to the normal derivative -i⁢Fk′⁢TisuperscriptsubscriptFknormal-′T-iF_{k}^{\prime}T of ωksubscriptωk\omega_{k} as desired (see [4, p. 87] for the calculation of this normal derivative). Since the periods of Fk′superscriptsubscriptFknormal-′F_{k}^{\prime}, k=1,…,n-1k1normal-…n1k=1,\dots,n-1 are well known to be linearly independent, and since the periods of the functions given by equation (4.4) are linear combinations of the periods of Λ⁢(z,ak)normal-Λzsubscriptak\Lambda(z,a_{k}), it follows that the periods of Λ⁢(z,ak)normal-Λzsubscriptak\Lambda(z,a_{k}) are independent. Identity (4.3) shows that the periods of B⁢(z,ak)BzsubscriptakB(z,a_{k}) are just minus the conjugates of the periods of Λ⁢(z,ak)normal-Λzsubscriptak\Lambda(z,a_{k}), and so it follows that the periods of B⁢(z,ak)BzsubscriptakB(z,a_{k}) are also independent. This completes the proof of Theorem 4.1.

5. Proof of Theorem 1.4

The proof of Theorem 1.4 follows a similar pattern to the arguments in the last section and is motivated by a result of Gustafsson stated as Lemma 4 in [6]. (In fact, there are two proofs of a closely related theorem given in [6] and a statement without proof of a converse that is relevant here. The proof we set out below is a third way of looking at this problem, and is shorter and simpler than the arguments given in [6], but it must be said that the meat of the argument is Gustafsson’s idea.)

Suppose that Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is an area quadrature domain and that hhh is a function in ℛ⁢(Ω)ℛnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(\Omega). It follows that h′superscripthnormal-′h^{\prime} has only finitely many poles in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega which are residue free poles of order two or more. Note that the singular part of Λ⁢(z,a)normal-Λza\Lambda(z,a) is equal to a non-zero constant times (z-a)-2superscriptza2(z-a)^{-2}, and the singular part of Λm⁢(z,a)superscriptnormal-Λmza\Lambda^{m}(z,a) is equal to a non-zero constant times (z-a)-(m+2)superscriptzam2(z-a)^{-(m+2)}. Hence, there is an element λλ\lambda in the span Λnormal-Λ\mathnormal{\Lambda} that has the same principal parts at each of the poles of h′superscripthnormal-′h^{\prime}. But such a function λλ\lambda is given as the derivative (∂/∂⁡z)z(\partial/\partial z) of a finite sum of the form

ϕ⁢(z)=∑n,mcn⁢m⁢Ganm⁢(z).ϕzsubscriptnmsubscriptcnmsuperscriptsubscriptGsubscriptanmz\phi(z)=\sum_{n,m}c_{nm}G_{a_{n}}^{m}(z).

Note that ϕϕ\phi vanishes on the boundary and that h-ϕhϕh-\phi also has removable singularities at the poles of hhh. Also note, that because hhh extends meromorphically to the double, there is a meromorphic function HHH on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega that extends smoothly to the boundary (and without singularities on the boundary) such that h⁢(z)=H⁢(z)¯hznormal-¯Hzh(z)=\overline{H(z)} for z∈b⁢Ωzbnormal-Ωz\in b\Omega. Now, given ggg in A∞⁢(Ω)superscriptAnormal-ΩA^{\infty}(\Omega), we may compute the inner product ⟨h′-λ,g⟩Ω=subscriptsuperscripthnormal-′λgnormal-Ωabsent\langle h^{\prime}-\lambda,g\rangle_{\Omega}=

i2⁢∫Ω(h′-λ)⁢g¯ d⁢z∧d⁢z¯=i2⁢∫b⁢Ω(h-ϕ)⁢g¯ d⁢z¯=i2⁢∫b⁢Ωh⁢g¯ d⁢z¯=i2⁢∫b⁢ΩH¯⁢g¯ d⁢z¯,formulae-sequencei2subscriptnormal-Ωsuperscripthnormal-′λnormal-¯gdzdnormal-¯zi2subscriptbnormal-Ωhϕnormal-¯gformulae-sequencednormal-¯zi2subscriptbnormal-Ωhnormal-¯gdnormal-¯zi2subscriptbnormal-Ωnormal-¯Hnormal-¯gdnormal-¯z\frac{i}{2}\int_{\Omega}(h^{\prime}-\lambda)\,\bar{g}\ dz\wedge d\bar{z}=\frac% {i}{2}\int_{b\Omega}(h-\phi)\bar{g}\ d\bar{z}=\frac{i}{2}\int_{b\Omega}h\,\bar% {g}\ d\bar{z}=\frac{i}{2}\int_{b\Omega}\bar{H}\,\bar{g}\ d\bar{z},

and the residue theorem implies that this last integral is equal to the complex conjugate of a finite linear combination of values of ggg and its derivatives at finitely many points in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega. There is an element κκ\kappa in the Bergman span that has the same effect when paired with ggg in the L2⁢(Ω)superscriptL2normal-ΩL^{2}(\Omega) inner product. Hence, since A∞⁢(Ω)superscriptAnormal-ΩA^{\infty}(\Omega) is dense in the Bergman space, h′-λ=κsuperscripthnormal-′λκh^{\prime}-\lambda=\kappa and we have proved that ℛ′⁢(Ω)⊂ℬ+Λsuperscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ωℬnormal-Λ\mathcal{R}^{\prime}(\Omega)\subset\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda}.

To prove the reverse inclusion, we will need to define some terminology. Note that we may differentiate identity (4.3) with respect to a¯normal-¯a\bar{a} to obtain the identity

(5.1) Bm⁢(z,a)⁢T⁢(z)=-Λm⁢(z,a)⁢T⁢(z)¯superscriptBmzaTznormal-¯superscriptnormal-ΛmzaTzB^{m}(z,a)T(z)=-\overline{\Lambda^{m}(z,a)T(z)}

for zzz in the boundary (where the superscript mmm indicate derivatives of order mmm with respect to a¯normal-¯a\bar{a} in the Bergman kernel and with respect to aaa in the Λnormal-Λ\Lambda-kernel). Given a function g=κ+λgκλg=\kappa+\lambda in ℬ+Λℬnormal-Λ\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda}, we define the complimentary function GGG to ggg to be the function gotten by conjugating all the constants in the linear combination, by changing terms of the form KbmsuperscriptsubscriptKbmK_{b}^{m} in ggg to Λbmsuperscriptsubscriptnormal-Λbm\Lambda_{b}^{m} in the complimentary function, and terms of the form Λbmsuperscriptsubscriptnormal-Λbm\Lambda_{b}^{m} to KbmsuperscriptsubscriptKbmK_{b}^{m}. In this way, we obtain a function GGG in ℬ+Λℬnormal-Λ\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda} that satisfies

g⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z)=-G⁢(z)⁢T⁢(z)¯gzTznormal-¯GzTzg(z)T(z)=-\overline{G(z)T(z)}

on the boundary. If γγ\gamma is a curve in the boundary of Ωnormal-Ω\Omega, then identity (5.1) shows that

∫γBm⁢(z,a) d⁢z=-∫γΛm⁢(z,a)¯ d⁢z¯,formulae-sequencesubscriptγsuperscriptBmzadzsubscriptγnormal-¯superscriptnormal-Λmzadnormal-¯z\int_{\gamma}B^{m}(z,a)\ dz=-\int_{\gamma}\overline{\Lambda^{m}(z,a)}\ d\bar{z},

and similarly for integrals of Λm⁢(z,a)superscriptnormal-Λmza\Lambda^{m}(z,a) by taking conjugates. Hence, ggg and GGG satisfy

(5.2) ∫γg⁢(z) d⁢z=-∫γG⁢(z)¯ d⁢z¯.formulae-sequencesubscriptγgzdzsubscriptγnormal-¯Gzdnormal-¯z\int_{\gamma}g(z)\ dz=-\int_{\gamma}\overline{G(z)}\ d\bar{z}.

Hence, if a period of ggg vanishes, then so does the same period of GGG.

First, we will prove the reverse inclusion in case Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is a simply connected area quadrature domain. Note that, in this case, elements of ℬ+Λℬnormal-Λ\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda} have single valued antiderivatives on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega which are meromorphic on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega because all the poles of elements of Λnormal-Λ\mathnormal{\Lambda} are residue free and are of order two or more. Let hhh be such an antiderivative, and write h′=κ+λsuperscripthnormal-′κλh^{\prime}=\kappa+\lambda as we did above. Let GGG be the complimentary function to h′superscripthnormal-′h^{\prime} and let HHH be an antiderivative of GGG. Let γzsubscriptγz\gamma_{z} denote a curve that starts at a boundary point bbb and moves along the boundary to another point zzz in the boundary. The formula (5.2) holds for the curve γzsubscriptγz\gamma_{z} for our complimentary functions g=h′gsuperscripthnormal-′g=h^{\prime} and G=H′GsuperscriptHnormal-′G=H^{\prime}. Hence, h⁢(z)-h⁢(b)hzhbh(z)-h(b) is equal to the conjugate of -(H⁢(z)-H⁢(b))HzHb-(H(z)-H(b)) on the boundary. This shows that hhh extends to the double, and the proof of the reverse inclusion is complete in the simply connected case.

We now turn to the multiply connected case. If κ+λκλ\kappa+\lambda is an element of ℬ+Λℬnormal-Λ\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda} with vanishing periods, then the periods of the complimentary function are also zero and we obtain two meromorphic functions hhh and HHH as we did above such that h′=κ+λsuperscripthnormal-′κλh^{\prime}=\kappa+\lambda and h′⁢T=-H′⁢T¯superscripthnormal-′Tnormal-¯superscriptHnormal-′Th^{\prime}T=-\overline{H^{\prime}T} on the boundary. Our task now is to show that we may adjust hhh and HHH by constants in order to make h=-H¯hnormal-¯Hh=-\overline{H} on the boundary so that we may conclude that hhh extends to the double. Choose a point bbb in the outer boundary of Ωnormal-Ω\Omega and adjust hhh and HHH by subtracting off constants h⁢(b)hbh(b) and H⁢(b)HbH(b) from hhh and HHH so that h⁢(b)=0hb0h(b)=0 and H⁢(b)=0Hb0H(b)=0. The calculation of the last paragraph shows h=-H¯hnormal-¯Hh=-\overline{H} on the outer boundary. The key to seeing that this identity persists on the inner boundaries is that integrals from bbb to a point b′superscriptbnormal-′b^{\prime} on an inner boundary also agree because of the relationships between the kernels and the Green’s function. Indeed, if γγ\gamma is a curve in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega that starts at bbb and goes to b′superscriptbnormal-′b^{\prime} and w∈Ωwnormal-Ωw\in\Omega is not in γγ\gamma, then it is well known that

(5.3) ∫γ∂∂⁡z⁢G⁢(z,w) d⁢z=-∫γ∂∂⁡z¯⁢G⁢(z,w) d⁢z¯.formulae-sequencesubscriptγzGzwdzsubscriptγnormal-¯zGzwdnormal-¯z\int_{\gamma}\frac{\partial}{\partial z}G(z,w)\ dz=-\int_{\gamma}\frac{% \partial}{\partial\bar{z}}G(z,w)\ d\bar{z}.

To see this, note that if ϕϕ\phi is real valued, then

∫γ∂⁡ϕ∂⁡z d⁢z=12⁢∫γ(∂⁡ϕ∂⁡x-i⁢∂⁡ϕ∂⁡y)⁢(d⁢x+i⁢d⁢y),subscriptγϕzdz12subscriptγϕxiϕydxidy\int_{\gamma}\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial z}\ dz=\frac{1}{2}\int_{\gamma}\left% (\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial x}-i\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial y}\right)(dx+i% \,dy),

and the real part of this integral is ϕ⁢(b′)-ϕ⁢(b)ϕsuperscriptbnormal-′ϕb\phi(b^{\prime})-\phi(b). Hence, since the Green’s function is real and vanishes on the boundary, the real parts of the two integrals in (5.3) vanish, and therefore, since they are conjugates of each other, the identity follows. Now differentiating (5.3) with respect to w¯normal-¯w\bar{w} and letting w=awaw=a yields that

∫γKm⁢(z,a) d⁢z=-∫γΛm⁢(z,a)¯ d⁢z¯.formulae-sequencesubscriptγsuperscriptKmzadzsubscriptγnormal-¯superscriptnormal-Λmzadnormal-¯z\int_{\gamma}K^{m}(z,a)\ dz=-\int_{\gamma}\overline{\Lambda^{m}(z,a)}\ d\bar{z}.

(This is just a reformulation of a well known fact going back to Bergman and Schiffer about the vanishing of the ββ\beta-periods of the meromorphic differentials obtained by extending Ka⁢d⁢zsubscriptKadzK_{a}dz to the backside of the double as the conjugate of -Λa⁢d⁢zsubscriptnormal-Λadz-\Lambda_{a}dz.) To continue, if we now choose such a curve γγ\gamma from bbb to b′superscriptbnormal-′b^{\prime} that avoids points where h′superscripthnormal-′h^{\prime} and H′superscriptHnormal-′H^{\prime} have singularities, this identity shows that

h⁢(b′)=∫γh′⁢d⁢z=-∫γH′¯⁢d⁢z¯=-H⁢(b′)¯.hsuperscriptbnormal-′subscriptγsuperscripthnormal-′dzsubscriptγnormal-¯superscriptHnormal-′dnormal-¯znormal-¯Hsuperscriptbnormal-′h(b^{\prime})=\int_{\gamma}h^{\prime}\,dz=-\int_{\gamma}\overline{H^{\prime}}% \,d\bar{z}=-\overline{H(b^{\prime})}.

Consequently, the identity h=-H¯hnormal-¯Hh=-\overline{H} extends to the inner boundary containing b′superscriptbnormal-′b^{\prime}. We may conclude that hhh extends to the double as a meromorphic function.

Theorem 4.1 yields that if Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is nnn connected, then there exist n-1n1n-1 points a1,a2,…,an-1subscripta1subscripta2normal-…subscriptan1a_{1},a_{2},\dots,a_{n-1} in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega such that the period matrix of K⁢(z,ak)KzsubscriptakK(z,a_{k}) is non-singular. Hence, given an element κ+λκλ\kappa+\lambda of ℬ+Λℬnormal-Λ\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda}, it is possible to subtract off a linear combination of the functions K⁢(z,ak)KzsubscriptakK(z,a_{k}) so to make the periods vanish. Hence, Theorem 1.4 yields that κ+λκλ\kappa+\lambda is equal to a function in ℛ′⁢(Ω)superscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ω\mathcal{R}^{\prime}(\Omega) modulo a linear combination of K⁢(z,ak)KzsubscriptakK(z,a_{k}). If we let ℬn-1subscriptℬn1\mathcal{B}_{n-1} denote the complex linear span of the K⁢(z,ak)KzsubscriptakK(z,a_{k}), then we can state that

ℛ′⁢(Ω)⊂ℬ+Λ⊂ℛ′⁢(Ω)+ℬn-1.superscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ωℬnormal-Λsuperscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ωsubscriptℬn1\mathcal{R}^{\prime}(\Omega)\subset\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda}\subset% \mathcal{R}^{\prime}(\Omega)+\mathcal{B}_{n-1}.

Next, we may use Theorem 1.4 to determine the image of ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω\mathcal{R}(b\Omega) under the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map in an area quadrature domain Ωnormal-Ω\Omega. Formula (4.2) combined with Theorem 1.4 shows that functions in the image are of the form κ1⁢T+λ1⁢T+κ2⁢T¯+λ2⁢T¯subscriptκ1Tsubscriptλ1Tnormal-¯subscriptκ2Tnormal-¯subscriptλ2T\kappa_{1}T+\lambda_{1}T+\overline{\kappa_{2}T}+\overline{\lambda_{2}T} where κ1subscriptκ1\kappa_{1} and κ2subscriptκ2\kappa_{2} are in ℬℬ\mathcal{B} and λ1subscriptλ1\lambda_{1} and λ2subscriptλ2\lambda_{2} are in Λnormal-Λ\mathnormal{\Lambda}. Identity (5.1) shows how to convert the term λ1⁢Tsubscriptλ1T\lambda_{1}T into a term of the form κ3⁢T¯normal-¯subscriptκ3T\overline{\kappa_{3}T} where κ3∈ℬsubscriptκ3ℬ\kappa_{3}\in\mathcal{B}, and the term λ2⁢T¯normal-¯subscriptλ2T\overline{\lambda_{2}T} into a term of the form κ4⁢Tsubscriptκ4T\kappa_{4}T where κ4∈ℬsubscriptκ4ℬ\kappa_{4}\in\mathcal{B}. Hence, when everything is combined, we obtain an expression in ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT\mathcal{B}T+\overline{\mathcal{B}T}.

Next, we show that every element in ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT\mathcal{B}T+\overline{\mathcal{B}T} is equal to the normal derivative of a harmonic function with rational boundary values in case Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is a simply connected area quadrature domain. Indeed, given a function ψ=κ1⁢T+κ2⁢T¯ψsubscriptκ1Tnormal-¯subscriptκ2T\psi=\kappa_{1}T+\overline{\kappa_{2}T} in this space, we may find functions holomorphic functions h1subscripth1h_{1} and h2subscripth2h_{2} on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega such that -i⁢h1′=κ1isuperscriptsubscripth1normal-′subscriptκ1-ih_{1}^{\prime}=\kappa_{1} and -i⁢h2′=κ2isuperscriptsubscripth2normal-′subscriptκ2-ih_{2}^{\prime}=\kappa_{2} where, by Theorem 1.4, h1subscripth1h_{1} and h2subscripth2h_{2} are in ℛ⁢(Ω)ℛnormal-Ω\mathcal{R}(\Omega). We may now write

ψ=-i⁢h1′⁢T+i⁢h2′⁢T¯.ψisuperscriptsubscripth1normal-′Tinormal-¯superscriptsubscripth2normal-′T\psi=-ih_{1}^{\prime}T+i\,\overline{h_{2}^{\prime}T}.

Such a function is the normal derivative of the harmonic function with rational boundary data h1+h2¯subscripth1normal-¯subscripth2h_{1}+\overline{h_{2}}.

Finally, we need to show that a representation of the form ψ=κ1⁢T+κ2⁢T¯ψsubscriptκ1Tnormal-¯subscriptκ2T\psi=\kappa_{1}T+\overline{\kappa_{2}T} is unique. If such an expression were equal to zero on the boundary, then κ1⁢T=-κ2⁢T¯subscriptκ1Tnormal-¯subscriptκ2T\kappa_{1}T=-\overline{\kappa_{2}T} and the left hand side of this expression is orthogonal to holomorphic functions in L2⁢(b⁢Ω)superscriptL2bnormal-ΩL^{2}(b\Omega) and the right hand side is orthogonal to the conjugates of holomorphic functions in L2⁢(b⁢Ω)superscriptL2bnormal-ΩL^{2}(b\Omega). Such functions must be given by sums of Fk′⁢TsuperscriptsubscriptFknormal-′TF_{k}^{\prime}T where Fk′superscriptsubscriptFknormal-′F_{k}^{\prime} are the well known holomorphic functions that arise via Fk′=2⁢(∂/∂⁡z)⁢ωksuperscriptsubscriptFknormal-′2zsubscriptωkF_{k}^{\prime}=2(\partial/\partial z)\omega_{k} where ωksubscriptωk\omega_{k} are the harmonic measure functions associated to the n-1n1n-1 inner boundary curves (see [4, p. 80] for a proof of this result). Hence κ1=∑k=1n-1ck⁢Fk′subscriptκ1superscriptsubscriptk1n1subscriptcksuperscriptsubscriptFknormal-′\kappa_{1}=\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}c_{k}F_{k}^{\prime}. We have just shown that κ1⁢Tsubscriptκ1T\kappa_{1}T is equal to the normal derivative of a harmonic function ϕϕ\phi with rational boundary values. However, κ1⁢Tsubscriptκ1T\kappa_{1}T is now also seen to be the normal derivative of a linear combination ωω\omega of ωksubscriptωk\omega_{k}, k=1,…,n-1k1normal-…n1k=1,\dots,n-1. Hence, ϕϕ\phi and ωω\omega differ by a constant, and it follows that the boundary values of ωω\omega are in ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω\mathcal{R}(b\Omega). But the functions in ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω\mathcal{R}(b\Omega) are the boundary values of meromorphic functions of the form R⁢(z,S⁢(z))RzSzR(z,S(z)) and, since ωω\omega vanishes on the outer boundary, it follows that ω≡0ω0\omega\equiv 0, and hence, that ϕϕ\phi is constant and hence, that κ1≡0subscriptκ10\kappa_{1}\equiv 0. Finally, it is an easy exercise to see that if

0≡∑n=1N∑m=0Mcn⁢m⁢Km⁢(z,bm),0superscriptsubscriptn1Nsuperscriptsubscriptm0MsubscriptcnmsuperscriptKmzsubscriptbm0\equiv\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sum_{m=0}^{M}c_{nm}K^{m}(z,b_{m}),

then all the coefficients cn⁢msubscriptcnmc_{nm} must be zero. (Indeed, such a function would be orthogonal to the Bergman space, and hence orthogonal to all polynomials. However, pairing a polynomial with the function in the Bergman span would yield a non-trivial sum of values and derivatives of the polynomial at finitely many points in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega, and it easy to construct a polynomial that would make this sum non-zero, yielding a contradiction.) We have shown that the representation of a function in ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT\mathcal{B}T+\overline{\mathcal{B}T} is uniquely determined.

The techniques of this section allow us to construct a one-sided inverse to the D-to-N map on rational functions in a simply connected area quadrature domain. Indeed, given a basic term like KamsuperscriptsubscriptKamK_{a}^{m} in the Bergman span we may express a meromorphic antiderivative of -i⁢hih-ih of KamsuperscriptsubscriptKamK_{a}^{m} on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega via a path integral formula. The proof of Theorem 1.4 reveals that hhh is in ℛ⁢(Ω)ℛnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(\Omega). Now, the normal derivative of the solution to the Dirichlet problem with boundary data h∈ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)hℛbnormal-Ωh\in{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) is equal to Kam⁢TsuperscriptsubscriptKamTK_{a}^{m}T. By this means, we may define a linear transformation LLL that maps Kam⁢TsuperscriptsubscriptKamTK_{a}^{m}T to the boundary values of hhh. The same procedure works for conjugates of terms of the form Kam⁢TsuperscriptsubscriptKamTK_{a}^{m}T. Since the representation of functions in ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT{\mathcal{B}}T+\overline{{\mathcal{B}}T} is unique, we obtain the operator LLL of the following theorem.

Theorem 5.1.

Suppose Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is a simply connected area quadrature domain. There is a natural linear transformation LLL which maps ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT{\mathcal{B}}T+\overline{{\mathcal{B}}T} onto ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) such that the D-to-N map composed with LLL is the identity.

6. The Neumann problem

The Szegő projection can be used to solve the classical Neumann problem for the Laplacian in planar domains in much the same way that it was used above to solve the Dirichlet problem. This process is described in [4, p. 87]. On a double quadrature domain, both the Szegő kernel SasubscriptSaS_{a} and the Garabedian kernel LasubscriptLaL_{a} extend to the double and are therefore rational on the boundary. Also, the functions Fj′superscriptsubscriptFjnormal-′F_{j}^{\prime} extend to the double (on area quadrature domains). If we combine these results with Theorem 20.1 in [4] and use the fact that the Szegő projection maps rational functions on the boundary to rational functions on the boundary, we obtain the following result.

Theorem 6.1.

If ψψ\psi is a rational function on the boundary of a double quadrature domain Ωnormal-Ω\Omega such that ∫b⁢Ωψ⁢d⁢s=0subscriptbnormal-Ωψds0\int_{b\Omega}\psi\,ds=0, then the solution to the Neumann problem with boundary data ψψ\psi is equal to

h+H¯+∑k=0n-1ck⁢ωkhnormal-¯Hsuperscriptsubscriptk0n1subscriptcksubscriptωkh+\overline{H}+\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}c_{k}\omega_{k}

where hhh and HHH are holomorphic functions on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega such that h′superscripthnormal-′h^{\prime} and H′superscriptHnormal-′H^{\prime} extend meromorphically to the double (and are therefore rational on the boundary) and the cksubscriptckc_{k} are constants.

7. Non-quadrature domains

All of the results of this paper carry over to non-quadrature domains if we define our basic objects differently. Suppose Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is a bounded nnn-connected domain with C∞superscriptCC^{\infty} smooth boundary. In this context, let ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) denote the space of C∞superscriptCC^{\infty} functions on the boundary that extend meromorphically to the double of Ωnormal-Ω\Omega, let ℛ⁢(Ω)ℛnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(\Omega) denote the space of meromorphic functions on Ωnormal-Ω\Omega that have boundary values in ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega), and let ℛ′⁢(Ω)superscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}^{\prime}(\Omega) denote the space of functions that are derivatives of functions in ℛ⁢(Ω)ℛnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(\Omega). It is proved in [5] that there are two Ahlfors maps f1subscriptf1f_{1} and f2subscriptf2f_{2} associated to two (rather generic) points in Ωnormal-Ω\Omega such that the meromorphic extensions to the double of Ωnormal-Ω\Omega form a primitive pair for the double. Hence, the function spaces just described can all be expressed in terms of rational functions of f1subscriptf1f_{1} and f2subscriptf2f_{2}. (Since fj¯=1/fjnormal-¯subscriptfj1subscriptfj\overline{f_{j}}=1/f_{j} on the boundary j=1,2j12j=1,2, these functions conveniently replace the Schwarz function in many situations.)

The main theorems of the paper in this context can be stated as follows.

Theorem 7.1.

Given a point aaa in a bounded smooth finitely connected domain Ωnormal-Ω\Omega,

Sa⁢ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)=𝒮+ℒ,subscriptSaℛbnormal-Ω𝒮ℒS_{a}{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega)=\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L},

where the function spaces on the right are understood to be restricted to the boundary. Furthermore,

Sa⁢ℛ⁢(Ω)=𝒮+ℒ.subscriptSaℛnormal-Ω𝒮ℒS_{a}{\mathcal{R}}(\Omega)=\mathcal{S}+\mathcal{L}.

The Szegő projection maps Sa⁢ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)subscriptSaℛbnormal-ΩS_{a}{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) onto the Szegő span.

The Dirichlet problem can be solved for boundary data in ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) by exactly the same methods we used in §3.

The theorem about the Bergman span also generalizes in a straightforward manner.

Theorem 7.2.

Suppose that Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is a bounded smooth finitely connected domain. If Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is simply connected, then

ℛ′⁢(Ω)=ℬ+Λ.superscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ωℬnormal-Λ{\mathcal{R}}^{\prime}(\Omega)=\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda}.

On a multiply connected area quadrature domain, ℛ′⁢(Ω)superscriptℛnormal-′normal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}^{\prime}(\Omega) is comprised of the functions in ℬ+Λℬnormal-Λ\mathcal{B}+\mathnormal{\Lambda} with vanishing periods. In both cases, the D-to-N map takes ℛ⁢(b⁢Ω)ℛbnormal-Ω{\mathcal{R}}(b\Omega) into ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT\mathcal{B}T+\overline{\mathcal{B}T}. In case Ωnormal-Ω\Omega is simply connected, this mapping is onto. Representations of functions ψψ\psi in ℬ⁢T+ℬ⁢T¯ℬTnormal-¯ℬT\mathcal{B}T+\overline{\mathcal{B}T} uniquely determine elements κ1subscriptκ1\kappa_{1} and κ2subscriptκ2\kappa_{2} in the Bergman span so that ψ=κ1⁢T+κ2⁢T¯ψsubscriptκ1Tnormal-¯subscriptκ2T\psi=\kappa_{1}T+\overline{\kappa_{2}T}.

Finally, we remind the reader that we explained in §4 why Theorem 4.1 holds in general bounded smooth domains. We remark here that the general result could also be proved from scratch using the definitions in this section and by repeating the proof given in §4 using these definitions.
